newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korea's monthly trade deficit narrows.
newsitem.headline: S.Korea's monthly trade deficit narrows.

text.p: South Korea said on Tuesday that its trade deficit dropped in March compared with February, sparking government optimism its shortfall target of $14 billion for the whole year could be met.
The trade ministry said the customs-cleared deficit eased to $1.88 billion in March from a shortfall of $2.09 billion in February and $3.47 billion in January.
But the March deficit gained 2.9 percent compared with a $446 million deficit a year earlier.
A ministry statement said the nation's trade deficit should continue to narrow month-on-month.
"The trade figures show signs of improving, which means we will be able to meet our yearly target," Kim Sang-yeol, the trade ministry's director general for trade policy, told reporters.
The ministry said it expected the trade deficit to narrow to $14 billion this year from $20.63 billion last year.
However, the shortfall rose to $7.43 billion in the first three months of this year, up from $4.17 billion in the same 1996 period.
"The government seemes to be too optimistic with its aggressive target," said Lim Choon-soo, head of research at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell Capital Markets Ltd.
"If export prices do not rebound, there's no way. It's up to global markets," he added.

Although South Korean exports rose in volume terms last year, the country's trade deficit hit an all-time high, bloated by a sharp fall in prices of key exports. Economists said export prices fell by 15 percent year-on-year.
But Kim said a production cut by chipmakers had helped drive up semiconductor prices on world markets.
Semiconductors are South Korea's largest single export item. They have been largely responsible for the huge trade shortfall because of a sharp drop in export prices.
South Korea exported $3.50 billion worth of semiconductors in the first quarter, down 43 percent from $6.14 billion a year earlier.
Kim said the unit spot price of 16 megabit dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chips, used to make personal computers, was now heading for $11 from $10.50 in March.
A ministry statement said the price stood at $9 in February and $8 in January.
"The price will rise further in April as Japanese chipmakers are expected to cut their output after finishing the fiscal year ending March," Kim said. "This will help increase our exports."
Exports, excluding semiconductors, rose 5.4 percent in March on steady sales of other key export items, including steel and petroleum products.
The ministry said slowing imports of foreign products would also help ease the rising trade deficit.
Imports of capital goods, accounting for 60 to 70 percent of total imports, continued to fall in March as facility investment by South Korean companies slowed.
Those imports fell 3.2 percent in the first 20 days of March, compared with a 2.2 percent decline in the month of February and a 0.5 percent rise in January.

"The economic slowdown has chilled investment sentiment among domestic companies and hurt domestic consumption. This will result in a sharp fall in import growth," said Lee Yong-man, an economist at LG Economic Research Institute.
He forecast facility investment by South Korean companies would fall 2.4 percent this year against a 8.2 percent rise a year earlier.
